The argument presented is a classic example of a logical fallacy known as "affirming the consequent." It occurs when the conclusion is based solely on the premise, without considering any other relevant information. In this case, the argument assumes that just because instructions were not explained clearly, it follows that they were not given. However, this conclusion does not necessarily follow from the premise, as there could be other reasons why instructions were not explained clearly, such as a lack of information or a mistake in the communication process.
